header.title:
Open Source
Flood Map
header.lead: share real-time flood information using social media

twitter-card.title: PetaJakarta.org is a free and open source real-time flood map.
twitter-card.description: PetaJakarta.org maps flood tweets and displays real-time information for navigation, safety, and response. Tweet #banjir with your geolocation enabled @petajkt to add your report to the map.

twitter-card-research.title: Report on social media for disaster response published
twitter-card-research.description: The report, PetaJakarta.org: Assessing the Role of Social Media for Civic Co-Management During Monsoon Flooding in Jakarta, Indonesia, was released on 15 June 2015...

share.title: Share flood information
share.content: See a flood? Share your report on the open source map

map.title: View the map
map.content: Check the map to see where the floods are right now

data.title: Open Data Collection
data.lead: The data from PetaJakarta.org is available for project partners and other researchers under an open license. If you'd like to use our data then we'd love to hear from you!

privacy.title: Privacy
privacy.text: Our open data collection archive does not contain individual tweets, but anonymised counts of Twitter activity at the 'RW' level. The live map at PetaJakarta.org does store any information about users; all information derived from location-enabled mobile devices is stored and displayed anonymously.

licensing.title: Licensing
licensing.text: Data is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License.

partners.title: Data Partners
partners.text: The PetaJakarta.org Open Data Collection is part of the PetaJakarta Collaborative Data Sharing Project, supported by the Australian National Data Service (ANDS). ANDS is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy Program. Visit http://ands.org.au or Research Data Australia (services.ands.org.au) to find out more.

records.text: View records of the data at the Research Data Australia portal

analytics.title: Analytics
analytics.analytics-off: PetaJakarta.org is not currently receiving reports; we will begin data collection and real-time flood mapping again in December 2015. Thank you to everyone who participated to make the map a success! See you again in the rainy season.

steps.title: 1. Launch your Twitter app
steps.content: use your Twitter account to post to the open source flood map

steps.title: 2. Enable geolocation
steps.content: geolocation pinpoints your report on the map

steps.title: 3. Tweet your report to the map
4. Follow @BPBDJakarta for official information
steps.content: get the latest info from the Jakarta Disaster Management Agency

data_partners.title: Data partners
data_partners.content: the open source flood map also accepts reports from these data partners

about.title: About
about.intro:
PetaJakarta.org is an applied research project led by the SMART Infrastructure Facility, in collaboration with BPBD DKI Jakarta and Twitter Inc. Additional data is supplied by Detik.com via Pasang Mata and Jakarta SmartCity via the Qlue application.

PetaJakarta.org harnesses the power of social media to gather, sort, and display information about flooding for Jakarta residents in real time.

The platform runs on the open source software CogniCity. This geosocial intelligence framework allows data to be collected and disseminated by residents through their location-enabled mobile devices to map flooding and water infrastructure in real-time.

To read more about the project background, structure, and objectives, please visit info.petajakarta.org.

privacy.title: Privacy
privacy.content: We do not store any information about users. Information derived from location-enabled mobile devices is mapped in real-time; this information is available through an open API for additional applications.

funding.title: Funding
funding.content: PetaJakarta.org is supported by the University of Wollongong Global Challenges Program, DMInnovation, and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of the Government of Australia. The Australian National Data Service supports the development and maintenance of the open data and open source software.

confirmed-reports.title: Confirmed reports from the last hour
confirmed-reports.instructions: Click to a report to see its location on the map
confirmed-reports.timestamp: show the current time on the map

map-information.title: Map information
map-information.acknowledgements:
This map displays real-time reports about flooding in Jakarta from the past hour.
To add your flood report, tweet #banjir @petajkt

Base maps

Map tiles © Mapbox.
Data by OpenStreetMap, under CC BY SA.

Infrastructure data

© SMART Infrastructure Facility, University of Wollongong

Reports

Derived from Twitter, Detik and Qlue data

River Gauges

Courtesy of BPBD DKI Jakarta

Flood Depths

From CogniCity in collaboration with BPBD DKI Jakarta

Software

Powered by CogniCity
Maps created using Leaflet

methods.Synopsis: Get confirmed flood reports from the last hour in point form

parameters.Name: format
parameters.Description: Defines the format of the requested reports data as either geojson (default) or topojson. If unspecified will default to geojson.

methods.Synopsis: Get unconfirmed flood reports from the last hour in point form

parameters.Name: format
parameters.Description: Defines the format of the requested reports data as either geojson (default) or topojson. If unspecified will default to geojson.

methods.Synopsis: Get a real-time count of flood reports from the past hour

parameters.Name: format
parameters.Description: Defines the format of the requested reports data as either geojson (default) or topojson. If unspecified will default to geojson.

parameters.Name: level
parameters.Description: Specifies area for the counts (e.g. country, state, city etc.). If unspecified defaults to Jakarta "subdistrict" level.

parameters.Name: hours
parameters.Description: Specifies the duration of the count, hours={1|3|6}. If unspecified defaults to past 1 hour.

methods.Synopsis: Access historical counts of flood reports per RW are in 1 hour blocks

parameters.Name: start_time
parameters.Description: The date and time of the start of the aggregate period as an ISO8601 string, representing a time from 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z until now. Note that basic form cannot be used and extended form (with hyphens and colons) must be used.

parameters.Name: blocks
parameters.Description: The number of 1-hour blocks to return, starting at 'start_time'.
